description: From Middle English pilegrim, from Old French pelegrin, from Latin peregrīnus (“foreigner”). Doublet of peregrine.
The change of –r...r– to –l...r– is an effect of dissimilation in early Romance; compare Italian cognate pellegrino.

entries.meaning: One who travels, especially on a journey to visit sites of religious significance.
examples: strangers and pilgrims on the earth

entries.meaning: (historical) A silk screen formerly attached to the back of a woman's bonnet to protect the neck.

verbs.description: pilgrim (third-person singular simple present pilgrims, present participle pilgriming, simple past and past participle pilgrimed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To journey; to wander; to ramble.
examples: [T]o all galleries, churches, sistine chapels, ruins, coliseums, and artistic or dilettante shrines he zealously pilgrimed[.]
